awd_titl_txt: STEM Indicators: Implementing a Model for Reporting and Research on State Assessment Policies for K-12 Science and Mathematics Education
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is funded in response to the Dear Colleague Letter Indicators for Monitoring Progress Toward Successful K- 12 STEM Education. The project will focus on Indicator 12: States? use of assessments that measure the core concepts and practices of science and mathematics disciplines. The project will develop a web portal of relevant information, augmented by state submissions, about each state?s assessments in mathematics and science. This portal would serve as a basis for an indicator that would allow key stakeholders in STEM education to both track and report, across states and over time, these important assessment policies. 

The project will work with a team of survey researchers and web developers, building upon a previously funded pilot project, to develop a web portal. The project staff will pre-populate the database supporting the web portal with publicly available information about state mathematics and science tests and their alignment to the state?s standards. They will supplement these data with survey data collected from each state?s assessment director, as well as state mathematics and science supervisors. The web portal will allow users to consider alignment information and make comparisons across states and over time.

STEM Indicators: Implementing a Model for Reporting and Research on State Assessment Policies for K-12 Science and Mathematics Education

 To better understand the mathematics and science assessment programs and policies at the state level and how these are aligned with content standards, NORC surveyed state education agencies in 2017-2018.  The responses from the SEAs were posted to the stem-assessment.org website (http://Stem-assessment.org).  In addition, four information briefs were posted on the landing page, to highlight some of the ways in which state education agencies, researchers and policy makers could use the information on the website. Below is a summary of the outcomes.

  • Brief #1 At what grade levels do states test key mathematics topics?
  • Brief #2 What types of science assessments do states use?
  • Brief #3 What are the most commonly used math assessments for 5th graders?
  • Brief #4 What are the most commonly used math assessments at high school?

  MATHEMATICS ASSESSMENT PROGRAMS AND POLICIES

In 2017-18, for grades 3-8, 12 states used the Smarter Balanced assessments (SBAC)  and four states plus D.C. used the math assessments developed with the PARCC Consortium. For comparison over time, in 2010 the SBAC proposal to the US ED included 30 member states, and the PARCC proposal included 24 states. At the high school level, 23 states use end-of-course assessments, 42 used comprehensive high school assessments, while 14 states administer both mathematics end-of-course assessments and a comprehensive high school math assessments. Assessments were reportedly used for a variety of policy purposes: school accountability, teacher accountability, to improve curriculum and instruction and alignment to standards. For high school, other purposes include supporting college and career readiness and high school graduation requirements.

 SCIENCE ASSESSMENT PROGRAMS AND POLICIES

In 2017-18, for grades 3-8, almost all of the states require a different science assessment instrument. At the high school level, states differed in whether they used End-of-course (EOC) assessments and/or Comprehensive Assessments.  EOC assessments are administered statewide in 22 states, with 18 states testing courses in Biology 1, 7 in chemistry, 3 in earth science, 3 in physics and 8 states testing in two or more courses. Overall, 33 states reported using Comprehensive Assessments. State comprehensive high school science assessments are administered at grade 11 in 26 states, at grade 10 in 10 states, in grade 9 in 4 states and grade 12 in two states.  Assessments were reportedly used for a variety of policy purposes: school accountability, teacher accountability, to improve curriculum and instruction and alignment to standards. For high school, other purposes include supporting college and career readiness and high school graduation requirements.

Modified by: Claudia Gentile
